8 a
Foree who were going homs on leave.
They were a colorful lot mostly
non-come radio operators,
flight mechanisa,
and gunners.
They all carried
Leather Jackete which will make sonething of a stir in their respeetiva
toms for on the back is painted a large Chinese flag, and below that
are Chinese characters which proclaim the wearer to be a foreign friend
of China.
After sleeping on a bench in the station I was so tired that I
could aleep on the airplane, and did so all the way to Karacki,
Arriving thare at 10 All, I bathed and shaved, then looked up our
PAA representative, whon I had met going through on my way out.
me that the next two PAA chips leaving bie station were both 100% hospital
whips and suggested that I tale the shorter northern route, which--with sone
reluctance to leave PAl-I decided to do rather than prolong my trip by
waiting at Karachi.
An ATC C-54 (DO-4) man acheduled out that some afternoon, and I
was ticketed.
Got away at 3850 and soon we were out over the ocean,
skirting tha shore of India--Iran-on across the Gulf of Persia--the high
rugged gray coast of Arsbia to Bahrein Island, where the Texas 011 Company
bas a great refinery.
Our scheduled stop at Arakan had to be cancelled as
a dust storm-clearly visible below us as we paased over--nade the airport
90 - 0".
On. to Habbaniyeh,
where we landed and got some very indifferent
show at the British Officers! Mess. We had two CAl men on board and the rest
-five in number--constitued a ferry crew of the Royal Canadian Air Force
ung left Canada the previous Wednesday and now on Saturday were on the way
The non-cons had to eat in the kitchen, despite all the protests of
their officers.
We got away again at 2:30 AM, Indian time, after an hour and a
hair on the ground, and flow on over Palestine and Trans-Jordan, Jerusalem,
and other historie places, arriving at Ceiro as daw we breaking.
The ship was serviced and after some four hours on the ground ne
took off en a most thrilling leg of the journey.
We flew low over Cairo
and the Nile.
Off to our left loomed the Pyramids an" the Sphins-I hoped
our new pilot would cirele but he dion't--on over ll. Alamein,
whene the
signa of "Monty'g" rout of Rommel are clearly viible in trenchen, abandoned
tanks,
shell holes and thousands of tracks across the sand.
On past Tobruk
and above Benglass, where we left the desert to cross over to Tripoli.
landed at Castel Benito for. food and drial for man and beast (1t's uncind
to vee that simile and refer to that beautiful airplane in such terms),
than flew non-stop across the Sahars Desert to Casablanca.
has nothing to recommend it!- I've seen some useless countryincluding the
land Albert Fall sold to Dobeney-but that Sahara In the linit in worth-
lessness.
Furthermore, to add insult to injury,
flying through a sand atorm, which me most unpleasant,
we harl a very rough hour
As we got out of
it I looked back to see it project upward an far as I could see, and we
were then 10,000 feet above the desert.
